node.title: Irreversibility issue in phase field fracture
node.bodyText:
Hello MOOSE experts
I am using the rate-dependent phase-field fracture equation for some thermo-mechanical problems. I found that the value of the phase-field parameter decreases in certain locations. Can you please suggest any possible reasons for such phenomena?
Best
Avtar
It's not clear to me from your description whether you are using moose modules or your app. Can you elaborate?
I am using MOOSE module for solving the phase-field fracture.
Great, then sharing a MWE that reproduces this issue is the easiest way we can help.
@asingh-mit any update on this?
Yes, It is solved. I used the bounds on the variable. It bounds are not used, irreversibility issue arises.

node.title: "Functionality is not available" error when using checkpoint
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE team
I recently tried to install moose on our HPC referring to the procedure from the installation pages. However, once I finished the compilation of libmesh and do some tests with "checkpoint=true" set, it returned the following error message
ERROR: Functionality is not available.
Make sure LIBMESH_HAVE_XDR is defined at build time
The XDR interface is not available in this installation
I simply ran the following commends while compiling the libmesh
scripts/update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh --with-dof-id-bytes=8 --enable-vtk --with-vtk-include=$VTKINCLUDE_DIR --with-vtk-lib=$VTKLIB_DIR
it seems that I should add some options to enable the XRD, which had never been set in the former procedure.
Could anyone inform me of the solution to this issue?
Thank you in advance
Did anyone encounter the same error message as me?
I imaging that there is some missing package on your machine that is causing libMesh to disable XDR support. If you look at text in during the configure, can you find the sections that mention XDR?

Thank you very much for your reply. I saved the log of compiling the libMesh, and it indeed mentioned that "XDR is not supported."
/////
checking for built-in XDR support... no
checking for XDR support in /usr/include/tirpc... no
////
I compiled this on our newest machine with 96 avx512 cores and essences:  gcc/8.3.1, openmpi/4.0.4, cmake/3.18.4,
which is wield since I changed to another machine with different compiling essences (24 avx2 cores w/ gcc/8.3.0, openmpi/4.0.2, cmake/3.18.4), and at that time, I could successfully compile the libmesh with XDR.
Is this issue occurred solely due to the differences of compelling packages, or is it also related to the usage of avx512 cores?
Thank you again, and look forward to your prompt reply.
@milljm Do you know what could be missing that is causing XDR to be disabled?
See this answer for future reference #20479 (reply in thread)

2: void mooseError<char const*>(char const*&&)
3: /home/xjb/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so.0(+0x78d054) [0x7f325842a054]

application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 0
[unset]: write_line error; fd=-1 buf=:cmd=abort exitcode=1
:
system msg for write_line failure : Bad file descriptor

Hello
Libmesh needs to be configured with netcdf4 to load this file.
Did you re-create the mesh file between the two versions? If you did, make sure to see #19264 before re-exporting it.
Guillaume
No,I have't re-creat it. the mesh file between the two version is same.
did you use conda for libmesh or did you install from the scripts in moose/scripts/?
I used conda, just like the MOOSE website.
@milljm conda build has libmesh compiled without HDF5 / netcfd4 right?
@roystgnr for the sake of closing this, how do we enable netcdf4 in libmesh again? I remember searching at the time and could not find it

NetCDF4 is automatically enabled whenever HDF5 is enabled, but HDF5 is never enabled automatically in libMesh (it's one of those things that often is preinstalled in /usr/lib/ but we never want to auto-include that whole directory lest we get whatever atavistic package versions are there).
If you already have HDF5, setting $HDF5_DIR is the best way to get us to check $HDF5_DIR/libs and $HDF5_DIR/include for libraries and headers.  If you have an install but it doesn't have that subdirectory structure, making a couple symbolic links in your own new $HDF5_DIR is currently the best way to handle it.
If you don't already have HDF5, you ought to be able to get it now just by using Moose's update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh, which will ask PETSc to build HDF5 if it doesn't find it elsewhere, after which point libMesh will autodetect PETSc's HDF5 installation.

node.title: In computing the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a symmetric rank-2 tensor, the PETSC LAPACK syev routine returned error code 2
node.bodyText:
Dear Moose users,
I am running a simulation using tensor mechanics and am seeing this error repeatedly. I tried to reduce the time step but it didn't help. I searched and found one relevant discussion  #16288.  My preconditioning and executioner blocks are as follows:
[Preconditioning]
  [./SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  [../]
[]

[Executioner]

  [./TimeStepper]
    type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    dt = 0.01
    growth_factor = 1.0000001
    cutback_factor = 0.9
    optimal_iterations = 15
    iteration_window = 2
    reject_large_step = true
    reject_large_step_threshold = 0.1
  [../]


  type = Transient
  nl_max_its = 15
  scheme = bdf2
  solve_type = PJFNK
  petsc_options_iname = -pc_type
  petsc_options_value = asm
  l_max_its = 40
  l_tol = 1.0e-3
  nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-5
  start_time = 0.0
  num_steps = 1000
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-5
[]

I am running my executable in parallel using mpi as mpiexec -n 4 ../../../.././drx__ti64-opt -i beta_transformed_Ti64_case1.i. I will be grateful for any guidance or references regarding this issue.
Warm Regards,
Ritam Chatterjee

Hello
Did you try to change a few parameters and see if the error goes away?
Like running it in serial, using lu for preconditioning etc
Guillaume

We use LAPACK subroutine at several places in TensorMechanics kernels/materials. It has nothing to do with the Solver option. Very likely, your problem has unrealistic deformation that causes eigendecomposition fail. Could you track where does the error come from?

Hi Guillaume, yes I am trying automatic_scaling = true,petsc_options_iname = -snes_ksp_ew according to this webpage https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/executioners/Steady.html. I will try lu with serial execution and other options and let you know.
Hi Wen, thank you for the response. Such failure is occurring during elastic deformation. I checked dislocation density, strain tensor components and Cauchy stress but the values seem alright. I will check other tensors such as Fp,Fe and let you know. I am simulating uniaxial compression for Ti6Al4V with beta phase at alpha grain boundaries. Is there anything else I can do to track this error?
I forgot what the name of that parameter is, but were you using EigenSolution or TaylorExpansion? Try switching to TaylorExpansion and see if that error persists.

I found it:
# decomposition_method = EigenSolution
decomposition_method = TaylorExpansion

Hi Gary, thank you for your reply. I am using ComputeFiniteStrain, which considers TaylorExpansion as default. However, from your and Wen's suggestion, I got the idea of adding use_displaced_mesh = true to all auxkernels and user objects in my input file as I had been facing convergence issues with the progress of plastic deformation. This seems to have helped definitely. Additionally, based on Guillaume's advice, I tried running in serial with lu and noticed good improvement in speed. Subsequently, I have run in parallel after making changes to the executioner block as follows:
[Executioner]

  [./TimeStepper]
    type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    dt = 0.001
    growth_factor = 1.0000001
    cutback_factor = 0.9
    optimal_iterations = 15
    iteration_window = 2
    reject_large_step = true
    reject_large_step_threshold = 0.1
  [../]


  type = Transient
  nl_max_its = 15
  scheme = bdf2
  solve_type = PJFNK
  petsc_options = -snes_ksp_ew
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -sub_pc_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'asm ilu'
  l_max_its = 40
  l_tol = 1.0e-3
  nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-5
  start_time = 0.0
  num_steps = 20000
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-5
  automatic_scaling = true
  scaling_group_variables = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
[]


Overall, the simulation is much faster now. However, I've again run into the same PETSC LAPACK error but after significantly more number of time steps. I will explore other options and check.
Thanks and regards,
Ritam
You could also try the ElementJacobianDamper which prevents over distortion of elements. I've had good experience using this damper.

Hi Gary, I will try ElementJacobianDamper and let you know. As a test, I added decomposition_method = EigenSolution to the tensor mechanics Master action block in my input file. Now, I haven't seen the error after almost ~15000 time steps with initial dt = 0.005. However, dt has now decreased to 1.5e-5. Is such a decrease expected in multiphase polycrystal plasticity problems?

Hi Guillaume,
I was able to figure out the problem. The time step was decreasing due to improper node set generation using BoundingBoxNodeSetGenerator as explained in this thread #20581. I did try ElementJacobianDamper but faced convergence issues, which I can't clearly remember now. I'll check again. I modified my Executioner block and now the simulation is significantly faster (4 times) than earlier when I run using MPI on 8 cores. The executioner block is below:
[Executioner]

  [./TimeStepper]
    type = IterationAdaptiveDT
    dt = 0.05
    growth_factor = 1.0000001
    cutback_factor = 0.9
    optimal_iterations = 15
    iteration_window = 2
    reject_large_step = true
    reject_large_step_threshold = 0.1
  [../]


  type = Transient
  nl_max_its = 15
  scheme = bdf2
  solve_type = PJFNK
  petsc_options = '-snes_ksp_ew'
  petsc_options_iname = '-ksp_gmres_restart -pc_type -pc_hypre_type -pc_hypre_boomeramg_max_iter'
  petsc_options_value = '201                hypre    boomeramg      4'
  l_max_its = 40
  l_tol = 1.0e-3
  nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-5
  start_time = 0.0
  num_steps = 20000
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-5
  line_search = none
  snesmf_reuse_base = false
  automatic_scaling = true
  scaling_group_variables = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
  [./Predictor]
    type = SimplePredictor
    scale = 1.0
    skip_after_failed_timestep = true
  [../]
[]

Warm regards,
Ritam

node.title: Inquiry about outputting the values of concentration of all the points in 2D CH model
node.bodyText:
Hi everyone,
Do you know how I can output all the points' concentration in a 2D CH model in each time step?
I know there is one command, called LineValueSampler.
However, from its introduction, it can only output 1D model's concentration, right? Because it can only output one line's variable's value, right? Can it output 2D model's concentration? Or, is there other command that can output all the points' concentration in 2D mode?
Does everyone have any good suggestion?
Thank you very much.
Best regards,

Hello
You can use this VectorPostprocessor (outputs to CSV) for all element values:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/vectorpostprocessors/ElementValueSampler.html
or if you have a 2D array of points you can fit as a long parameter:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/vectorpostprocessors/PointValueSampler.html
Guillaume

Hi, Guillaume,
Thank you very much for your quick response.
Do you mean that I need to write the command as shown below?
[VectorPostprocessors]
[./element_value_sampler]
type = ElementValueSampler
variable = 'c'
sort_by = id
[../]
[]
How should I set the 'sort by' option? The 'sort by' option is set as id? And then I can get all the points' concentration? Will the csv file give me only one line and contains all of the points' concentration or it will be distributed by x axis and y axis?
And for your second suggestions, it seems that pointvaluesampler can only output several specific point's value, not the whole 2D matrix...

For the second suggestion, you could input a 2D matrix of points, it ll just not be very pretty, a very long parameter essentially.
I think the first suggestion should do what you want, if the Elements actually form the 2D matrix of points that you want

Better answer to this is to define a nodeset then use the NodalValueSampler
or a new subdomain then the ElementValueSampler
nevermind no need for defining a subset since you want ALL values. Answer remains the same.

Can you show me an example? How to use it?
…

node.title: Formal definition of mesh bias parameter
node.bodyText:
I have looked for, but have been unable to find, a quantitative definition for how the mesh bias variable behaves.  Is this essentially a geometric series, where the distance between node 0 and n for n > 0 is given by:
distance = sum (a r^(n - 1) ) = a(1 - r^(n-1)) / 1 - r
where a is the first spacing (i.e. between nodes 0 and 1), r is the bias value and n is the node number?
I suspect there is a very simple explanation for this but I run into problems as there are three parameters to define in the mesh block: the number of nodes, the distance spanned and the bias value.  Does this mean that by choosing the length of a particular dimension and the number of nodes I wish to use, the bias value is fixed?  But if the geometric nature is true then one should also be able to define the first spacing, a.   The more I look at it the further away I get from understanding it!  If there is a definition on the MOOSE help pages then I would appreciate a link to it.  Many thanks in advance for the help.

Hello
Which mesh generator is this for?
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/mesh/GeneratedMesh.html ?
I looked at the code, and the a (standard spacing in the non-biased case, not the first spacing anymore) is being modified to respect the number of nodes, the bias value and the distance in that generator.
Guillaume

On a quick note we re getting more mesh biasing work in this PR. Not sure that is relevant for you
#20638

node.title: Creation of individual output files for multiapp reset times
node.bodyText:
Hi Guillaume,
You might've remember this work (#18549) which happened quite a while ago. I observed an odd thing concerning the creation of exodus outputs while working on my recent activity on QuadraturePointMultiapp. The specification of list of reset_time's given in the input enables the creation of output files for all these times which would multiply if we are using a large mesh. Is there a possibility of suppressing the creation of such files either by setting options in the input file or by other means?
[MultiApps]
  [sub]
    type = QuadraturePointMultiapp
    input_files = 'sub_gs_uniaxial_noCPFE.i'
    output_in_position = true
    execute_on = timestep_end
    reset_time = '0.02 0.03 0.04 0.05'
  []
[]



Kind regards,
Arun

Hello
You can change the amount of output by setting in the MultiApp input file (sub_gs_uniaxaiaal_noCPFE.i) a different exodus output.
Then you can set an execute_on to limit the output to certain times in the simulation.
You can also disable output by some of the subapps by passing command line arguments (Outputs/exodus=false) to certain subapps. This is done in the [MultiApps] block of the main app.
Option 1:
Instead of
[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

you set
[Outputs]
  [exo]
    type = Exodus
    execute_on = FINAL
  []
[]

Option 2:
[MultiApps]
  [sub]
    type = QuadraturePointMultiapp
    input_files = 'sub_gs_uniaxial_noCPFE.i'
    output_in_position = true
    execute_on = timestep_end
    reset_time = '0.02 0.03 0.04 0.05'
    cli_args = 'Outputs/exodus=false' # passed to all of them! otherwise need one param per quadrature point
  []
[]

Hi Guillaume,
Option 2 does not create any of the exodus files at all, which is not the preferred case. Option 1 does seem to limit the formation of outputs, except for the first reset_time. This also requires execute_on = FINAL to be set at the sub-app output block. One weird thing being that the default outputfiles (e.g.,  main_sub0.e) are not created in this case.
Option: 1

Kind regards,
Arun

Option 1:
you can also create a custom execute_on to output only at given times. Will require coding
Option 2:
yes you will need a really long input of exodus=false/true if you want to customize. You can create that with a python script though

Looks like option 1 seems to be the more relevant one. I will see if i can implement something which can only output the default output files suppressing the other ones for times specified in the 'reset_time" list. I may need to priorities other tasks before taking up this work.
I think there may be a 3rd option leveraging the Controls system. I ll have to check though and I ll report back

so you could use a Control on the Outputs/Exodus block
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/controls/ConditionalFunctionEnableControl.html
based on the value of a Function that is the value of a postprocessor
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/FunctionValuePostprocessor.html
for that postprocessor you would set the value from main app using this:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/transfers/MultiAppReporterTransfer.html
not super straightforward

@abarun22 Have you always been getting the *.e-s002 exodus outputs?  I recently noticed some of these showing up in my simulations that used to only output a single exodus file on the subapp.  Does it output one of these files everytime a reset is hit?

Yes Lynn, i've always been getting these additional exodus outputs whenever
i am resetting my sub-apps through `reset_time` parameter. I recently
enabled this parameter to accept a list of times for which the reset
happens. This triggered a creation of series of files for all the reset
times, that bloated my working directory. Working with Guillaume to find a
solution for this issue, so that only the default 'end of simulation' files
are created.
…

 @abarun22 <https://github.com/abarun22> Have you always been getting the
 *.e-s002 exodus outputs? I recently noticed some of these showing up in my
 simulations that used to only output a single exodus file on the subapp.
 Does it output one of these files everytime a reset is hit?

Ok I think I understand the problem better now. You just want to get rid of the -s002 files. I ll have a look into that. I was just giving general advice into how to reduce the number of exodus files.

Hi Guillaume,
Yes, you would need to specify the 'reset_apps' parameter mandatorily to trigger the app reset, without which it will not be possible. The remedy would be to comment out the part of code that creates these extra files whenever user specifies a number under  'reset_apps'. Probbaly it could be an easy fix.
Kind regards,
Arun
ah you're right. This is troublesome in itself. You could specify a reset_time and have it be completely ignored if you forgot to specify a reset_apps

I fixed that part of the problem in a recent PR (the possibility for a parameter to be ignored)
Once #20269 or something similar is merged we will have the main problem solved too, you wont need to reset the app, just trigger a recover which is lighter

node.title: Reference Points in MOOSE
node.bodyText:
Is there a way to create a reference point in MOOSE which I can use to apply the load for my model?
Thanks in advance.

Hello
Sorry we missed this. Yes you can create a nodeset using this
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/ExtraNodesetGenerator.html
then you should apply the load on that nodeset
Guillaume

node.title: Unable to read exodus file
node.bodyText:
I am using Cubit to mesh a geometry and import exodus '.e' file in MOOSE. But I am getting following error:
*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "mesh", of type "FileMesh".
Unable to nodeset ID: -123.
Am I missing something during meshing or importing file in MOOSE?

Hello
I havent seen this error before. Can you share your mesh file? Either here or by email at my address listed on github
Guillaume

Also you should try to use this instead of specifying the mesh directly in the [Mesh] block:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/FileMeshGenerator.html
